newsitem.title: GERMANY: German doctors anaesthetise foetus in the womb.
newsitem.headline: German doctors anaesthetise foetus in the womb.

text.p: Two German doctors have for the first time anaesthetised a foetus for a life-saving operation in the womb while leaving the mother conscious, an advance which should make it easier to operate on unborn children in future.

Doctors Bernd Ebeling and Manfred Hansmann made the breakthrough in an operation to give blood to the unborn child of a 29-year-old mother, endangered because of a potentially fatal blood incompatibility, Bonn University said on Wednesday.
The transfusion involves inserting a needle through the mother's abdomen and into the umbilical cord, and requires the foetus to make no sudden movements.

Until now, this has meant anaesthetising the mother, with risks to her health and an uncontrolled effect on the child, or giving the foetus a substance to paralyse its muscles, but without dulling the pain.
Research indicates that foetuses can feel significant pain from the sixth month of pregnancy.

Ebeling and Hansmann delivered the anaesthetic through the umbilical cord, monitoring the child to be sure that its heart beat normally throughout the 10-minute operation, and that its movements returned to normal when the anaesthetic wore off.
A statement from the university said the advance would make it easier to carry out other kinds of minimally invasive operations on unborn children in future.
